column1: White Bear Lake is a city in Ramsey County in the state of Minnesota. A small portion of the city also extends into Washington County. The population was 23
column2: 769 at the 2010 census. The city is located on White Bear Lake
column3: one of the largest lakes in the Minneapolis–Saint Paul metropolitan area.

column1: The city is named after its largest lake
column2: White Bear Lake. American writers have delivered differing versions of the legend that explains the origin of the name. In her book Indian Legends of Minnesota
column3: Mrs. Carl T. Thayer writes that "It is said that a Sioux maiden fell in love with a Chippewa brave. She
column5: on learning that her father planned war against the Chippewa
column6: ran to her lover and warned him. The brave went alone into the Sioux village to ask for peace and the hand of the maiden. Before the Chief would agree
column7: the Chippewa would have to do a brave deed.""The lovers usually met on Manitou Island. One day
column8: as the brave approached the Island
column9: anticipating a meeting with his beloved
column12: a great white bear attacking her. He dashed to her rescue. Freed
column13: she ran to get help from her father and the other Sioux. Returning
column14: they saw the brave sink his knife into the bear. But too late
column15: they both fell to the ground dead. Slowly
column17: the spirits of the brave and the bear rose from their prone bodies. It is said that even today
column19: the spirits of the bear and the brave wander the Island eternally in search of each other."In Mark Twain's memoir Life on the Mississippi
column22: with one plunge of the blade of his knife
column23: opened the crimson sluices of death
column24: and the dying bear relaxed his hold. "That night
column25: there was no more sleep for the band or the lovers
column26: and as the young and the old danced about the carcass of the dead monster
column27: the gallant warrior was presented with another plume
column28: and ere another moon had set he had a living treasure added to his heart. Their children for many years played upon the skin of the white bear – from which the lake derives its name
column29: and the maiden and the brave remembered long the fearful scene and rescue that made them one
column30: for Kis-se-me-pa and Ka-go-ga could never forget their fearful encounter with the huge monster that came so near sending them to the happy hunting ground."

column2: The Legend of White Bear Lake
column3: was produced by Youth Music Theatre UK and produced at the Barbican Theatre
column5: England. Book music and lyrics were by Caroline Wigmore (originally from Minnesota) and Jennifer Green. The musical told the tale of the two lovers and the white bear after whom the lake is named.

column1: The railroad was the largest man-made happening in White Bear Lake. On September 10
column3: the Lake Superior and Mississippi Railroad officially opened the extension to White Bear Lake. This was a gala occasion. Ten platform cars of 300 men and four passenger cars for 200 ladies made the trip from St. Paul.

column2: Mark Twain had included White Bear Lake as the resort in his "Life on the Mississippi."  The "American Travelers Journal" 1881 proclaimed
column3: "One of the most popular resorts in the magic northlands is White Bear Lake."  Barnum's hotel became the Leip House
column8: and boats. F.C. Williams opened the Williams House on the Murray property on Lake Avenue.  James Waters opened the White Bear House at the depot.  In 1879
column9: the Ramaley Pavilion was opened and described as "perhaps the finest structure around the lake" (Breeze 1890). There was Lake Side Cottage on Lake north of 6th and "Château gay."  Shady Side
column10: Bachelor's Rest and Hotel Benson were three of the resorts at Bald Eagle Lake.

column1: The Cottage Park summer residents built a club house in 1881 where they had their meals
column3: the Manitou Implement Co. developed the Island for cottages with the added important feature of water works. The "Fillebrown" house on Lake Avenue was built in 1879 by C.P. Noyes.  It was purchased in 1881 by Judge George Young and in 1905 purchased by the J. Walter Fillebrown family who donated the house to the White Bear Lake Area Historical Society in the 1970s.

column1: The City of White Bear Lake was incorporated in 1921.

column1: The murder of three-year-old Dennis Jurgens in 1965 at the hands of his adoptive mother
column3: was arguably the biggest scandal to hit the town with her conviction in 1987.  The story was recounted in Barry Siegel's true crime novel A Death in White Bear Lake.

column2: the Lakeshore Players Community Theater was organized. Lakeshore Players formerly operated out of a former church building constructed in 1889
